HBV polymerase interacts with STING and inhibits its K63-linked ubiquitination. it is associated with loss of STING function and consequent impairment of IRF3 activation and IFN-induction and the antiviral response. many viruses have been reported to target it for subversion of the host innate immunity. in this study, we demonstrated that HBV Pol markedly impaired K63-linked ubiquitination of STING by physically associating with it through the RT/RH region. however, it had a moderate effect on STING dimerization, which is essential for STING self-activation and subsequent downstream signaling culminating in the induction of type I IFN (21) the recruitment of TBK1 and IRF3 by STING is also required for the activation of STING signaling overexpression of DDX3 could restore the inhibitory effect of HBV polymerase on STING signaling. this result partly excludes the possibility that Pol inhibits STING-mediated type I IFN production mainly by dampening its K63-linked ubiquitination. however, the precise delineation of how Pol affects STING-mediated signaling requires further understanding of the molecular mechanisms involved in STING activation. pol was also shown to abrogate IFN- signaling by suppressing the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2 in Huh7 cells (79). detailed studies of the TP domain of Pol revealed its association with protein kinase C-delta (PKC-), resulting in inhibition of PKC- phosphorylation. the RH domain was able to interfere with nuclear transportation of STAT1/2 through competitive binding to importin-5 (80).
